Award.AwardTitle: CM/Collaborative Research: A Computational Approach to Customizing Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Creating physical things,including shapes and structures, cyber-mechanical devices, and other functional artifacts and machines, is a laborious and often error-prone process, typically limited to domain experts and engineers. Often the manufacturing expert is distinct from the device designer, leading to a knowledge and ability gap that makes it difficult if not impossible for end users to create custom products. Nonetheless, there is a need for customization and personalization in product design across many application spaces, including, for example, healthcare, sports gear, furniture, and vehicles. This project will investigate algorithms, methods, and tools to allow casual end-users to leverage the knowledge of engineering experts to easily and effectively create validated and verifiable manufacturable designs for custom objects. The project will engage students in K-12 schools and community colleges, women, and minorities through the software and design artifacts, thus promoting and inspiring STEM education.

This project will develop a complete computational pipeline to enable designing and manufacturing parameterized objects that can be customized and instantiated by non-experts. More specifically, given a parametric Computer Aided Design (CAD) model, the investigators will develop translation methods that convert it to a customizable digital model with a small number of intuitive parameters. The framework will also provide mechanisms to compose these digital models into new ones. Given desired parameter values, each model will be translated to a manufacturing process and its digital instructions. To this end, a number of fundamental questions will be addressed including: (1) general representations for customizable, manufacturable digital models, (2) translation processes for converting standard parametric CAD models to these new representations, (3) methods that enable composition of these digital models into new ones, and (4) computational backends that translate the new digital models into digital instructions that drive specific manufacturing machines.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we develop a complete computational pipeline (backend) that enables designing and manufacturing of customizable objects that can be used by everyone. Specifically, we use flat-pack furniture as an example to demonstrate our system.  We create a design tool that allows casual end-users to easily generate customizable, manufacturable, and easy-to-assemble flat-pack furniture designs. We also build an extensible framework that enables users to create complex furniture designs by hierarchically composing pre-defined designs based on functionality. We generate an algorithm that greatly increases the feasibility and flexibility of the design process through automatically detecting and inserting necessary connections and joints for user-defined furniture models, and a representative variety of (scaled) furniture designed, fabricated, and assembled using our proposed system.

Meanwhile, we develop a collaboration design interface (frontend) by combining AR/VR technology to facilitate the design process in an intuitive way. This design interface enables virtual collaboration between AR and VR environments and adopts modeling-in-context approach, using physical environment and existing objects as a reference of the virtual design. Also this interface has the following features: applies both 2D and 3D, intuitive and user-defined gestures as design commands and generates parameterized and fabrication-aware 3D models.

By combining the computational frontend/backend, our computational design pipeline can revolutionize the way we design and fabricate new objects, enabling the rapid development of engineered systems by reducing their design and fabrication time by orders of magnitude. Our systems can be available for numerous applications, such as personalized, custom consumer products, prosthetics, orthotics, health care etc. We have released our design package as open-source tools, which is available to end-users, designers, engineers, manufacturing workforce and artists. Also our design tool can be integrated into course curricula for K-12 schools as well as community colleges, which will promote and inspire STEM education, especially among women and underrepresented minorities.


Last Modified: 03/24/2021
Modified by: Ankur M Mehta

    Wenzhong Yan
    Ankur M Mehta
    Design for Everyone Workflow
  • a) Collaborative users enter either AR or VR environment to access a shared virtual design space; b) the AR user scans the targeted environment, (c) both users collaboratively design the object using intuitive gestures; (d) the system directly generates manufacturing specifications.
    Qiong Hu
    Copyrighted
    Ankur M Mehta
    FAVECAD is a fabricable, personalized, and environment-aware design tool
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In this project, we develop a complete computational pipeline (backend) that enables designing and manufacturing of customizable objects that can be used by everyone. Specifically, we use flat-pack furniture as an example to demonstrate our system. We create a design tool that allows casual end-users to easily generate customizable, manufacturable, and easy-to-assemble flat-pack furniture designs. We also build an extensible framework that enables users to create complex furniture designs by hierarchically composing pre-defined designs based on functionality. We generate an algorithm that greatly increases the feasibility and flexibility of the design process through automatically detecting and inserting necessary connections and joints for user-defined furniture models, and a representative variety of (scaled) furniture designed, fabricated, and assembled using our proposed system. Meanwhile, we develop a collaboration design interface (frontend) by combining AR/VR technology to facilitate the design process in an intuitive way. This design interface enables virtual collaboration between AR and VR environments and adopts modeling-in-context approach, using physical environment and existing objects as a reference of the virtual design. Also this interface has the following features: applies both 2D and 3D, intuitive and user-defined gestures as design commands and generates parameterized and fabrication-aware 3D models. By combining the computational frontend/backend, our computational design pipeline can revolutionize the way we design and fabricate new objects, enabling the rapid development of engineered systems by reducing their design and fabrication time by orders of magnitude. Our systems can be available for numerous applications, such as personalized, custom consumer products, prosthetics, orthotics, health care etc. We have released our design package as open-source tools, which is available to end-users, designers, engineers, manufacturing workforce and artists. Also our design tool can be integrated into course curricula for K-12 schools as well as community colleges, which will promote and inspire STEM education, especially among women and underrepresented minorities.
